definition: Zhang Fei (168-221), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, famous as fearsome fighter and lover of wine
surname Zhang
to open up/to spread/sheet of paper/classifier for flat objects, sheet/classifier for votes
to fly
lit. Zhang Fei fights Yue Fei/fig. an impossible combination/an impossible turn of events (idiom)

sentences.english: Farther ahead there were lanterns and candles alight while Zhang Fei drank in his tent.
sentences.chinese: 遥望张飞大明灯烛，正在帐中饮酒。

sentences.english: At the edge of human pointing, Zhang Fei had spent 50 yuan of money.
sentences.chinese: 在边上人的指点下，张飞足足花了50多元钱。

sentences.english: Zhang took out needle and line taking a closer look, and finally found a hole behind the needle.
sentences.chinese: 张飞拿出针与线左看右看，终于发现了针后面的小孔。

sentences.english: The Temple of Zhang Fei has been rebuilt.
Liu Bei retired calmly, but Zhang Fei was furious.
sentences.chinese: 刘备退休的很平静，但张飞怒不可遏。

sentences.english: Zhang Fei, monitor of their class, is good at English.
sentences.chinese: 张飞是他们的班长，英语很棒。

sentences.english: Zhang Fei stamped toward Dong Zhuo's tent, holding firmly a sharp sword.
sentences.chinese: 张飞盖章的帐篷，董卓朝持有坚决一把利刃。

sentences.english: This can not beat Zhang Fei, he decided to street performers.
sentences.chinese: 这可难不倒张飞，他决定到街头卖艺。

sentences.english: The triumphant Zhang Fei reported to Chengdu.
sentences.chinese: 张飞大获胜捷，报入成都。

sentences.english: I still have two finesses' to make my slam.
sentences.chinese: 我还有两张飞牌来完成满贯。

definition: Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama
Zhao Yun (-229), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
Lü Bu (-198), general and warlord
Huang Zhong (-220), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, portrayed as an old fighter

Cao Cao (155-220), famous statesman and general at the end of Han, noted poet and calligrapher, later warlord, founder and first king of Cao Wei 曹魏, father of Emperor Cao Pi 曹丕/the main villain of novel the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
Zhou Yu or Chou Yü (175-210), famous general of the southern Wu kingdom and victor of the battle of Redcliff/in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, absolutely no match for Zhuge Liang
Ma Chao (176-222), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
Han Xin (-196 BC), famous general of first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1]
Lü Meng (178-219), general of the southern state of Wu
Cheng Yaojin (589-665), aka 程知節|程知节[Cheng2 Zhi1 jie2], Chinese general of the Tang dynasty
courtesy name of Zhuge Liang 諸葛亮|诸葛亮[Zhu1 ge3 Liang4]
Sun Ce (175-200), general and major warlord of the Later Han Dynasty

Jiang Ziya (c. 1100 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), partly mythical sage advisor to King Wen of Zhou 周文王[Zhou1 Wen2 wang2] and purported author of “Six Secret Strategic Teachings” 六韜|六韬[Liu4 tao1], one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1]
Pang De (-219), general of Cao Wei at the start of the Three Kingdoms period, victor over Guan Yu 關羽|关羽/Pound (name)/Ezra Pound (1885-1972), American poet and translator
